title: Between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018, will an armed group from Iraq engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Iraq?
preds: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer nec odio. Praesent libero. Sed cursus ante dapibus diam. Sed nisi. Nulla quis sem at nibh elementum imperdiet. Duis sagittis ipsum. Praesent mauris. Fusce nec tellus sed augue semper porta. Mauris massa. Vestibulum lacinia arcu eget nulla. Class aptent taciti sociosqu ad litora torquent per conubia nostra, per inceptos himenaeos.

This is not beyond the realms of possibility, increasing isolation of Sunni communities and the possibility that redevelopment will be not be evenly distributed will be triggers to a return to violence and dissent.
I think the Iraqis have pretty much had it beat out of them. I just don't think they could muster enough rage, weaponry and involvement to kill that many people.
ISIS can still kill large numbers of civilians without holding territory.

Iraq is making progress in security. Kuwait said that they're happy with security. Also Iraq is trying to bring investors into their country and they will not allow anything like that happen. The US military is also maintaing a prescence in Iraq.

ISIS is resurging on Iraq and they will try to kill as many Shia and Kurdish civilians as they can through a campaign of terrorism, as well as killing any Sunnis who opposed or betrayed them. I expect they will easily top 1,000 victims of car bombings and other acts by the end of the year. At the same time, Iraqi security forces will not show much care for civilians as they try to suppress ISIS; there may not be large-scale killings of suspected ISIS sympathizers but a lot of suspects being disappeared or killed in small actions.

Elections in May will result in Shia-influenced violence in Southern Iraq.  Tensions in Kirkuk over Kurd/Iraqi disputed oil region also has the ability to escalate should the Kurds coalesce around that issue.

Unlikely based on wording of question, especially the 'systematic' peice:   " In general, unrelated executions of individuals or the accidental killing of civilians in war will not be considered a campaign to systematically kill civilians. If an armed group is engaged in multiple campaigns that systematically kill civilians (e.g., in different geographic areas, or targeted against separate civilian groups) those fatalities will be counted separately"
Only real chance of this is some renewed effort against the Kurds.
Continuing instability and lack of broad American or European security forces make for a moderate possibility for such violence.
Unless a new militia starts up with significant numbers and fire power I do not foresee this happening.

This projection requires an armed group in Iraq to have the capabilities to kill 1,000 or more civilians. Currently, the Iraqi government and Turkey have ISIS and the PKK pinned to a point where neither group can conduct significant operations. This lack of capability greatly reduces the chances that serious armed conflict will occur in Iraq within the next year.

Our military and Intel is growing stronger and stronger. Within the past 11 months isis, Taliban, and rebel forces have witnessed a huge loss of territory. We have them on the run and are hiding. As long as our forces don't let off the pressure and keeping pushing, there will be a low chance of a coordinated large scale attacks
ISIS is not completely defeated but it the probability of 1000 civilian casualties is low.
Not likely under current political conditions. ISIS is toast.

I believe the chance that a group systematically kills 1000+ Iraqi civilians in the next year is low but by no means impossible. Iraq is still reeling in the North after being liberated from ISIS control, and they need time to recover. The situation is becoming increasingly stable as ISIS loses territory and therefore power/control, and there is nothing to indicate the rise of a new group that will commit an act like this, nor any indication that there will be a change in Iraqi leadership and that the government would harm the civilian population. However, I still say 20% because ISIS gained power relatively quickly and it or another group like it could potentially come out of the ashes and do just that.
Not sure about this one - unfortunately so many dead in this country already!
No chance especially after total defeat of ISIS.
After the decline od Daesh, massive death tolls are greatly reduced from occuring.
While Iraq is still unstable, I believe most fighting in 2018 will be between militias and state forces. With the Islamic State influence decreasing throughout 2018, civilian deaths should decrease.

I believe that the fighting in Iraq will continue to decline as the Iraqui-US coalition continue to win against ISIS.  With the major strong point in Iraq retaken from ISIS last year, I believe terrorist groups and civil fighting will shift to current unstable countries. Pakistan has been getting attacked more frequently by terrorist groups and with the current US government creating diplomatic uncertainty, I believe this will invite for more violence and fear. Because of this hypothetical increase in violence in Pakistan, the violence and civilian deaths in Iraq should drop.
Have read and reread examples and FAQ. Lowering as a result of the specific criteria required.
Better than even chance of sectarian violence.
ISIS has been disorganized. Unless a new group is spawned, a group that wants to wrest control from central government, I can envision no such armed group attack against civilians in Iraq.
ISIS is still the most likely suspect if something like this comes to pass.
With the vacuum left in the North from the fall of ISIS in that region.  There is a strong possibility that a group in that area will fight to fill that vacuum.
Iran has declared victory against ISIS.  There is not that much concentrated resistance to cause that many casualties in Iraq.

Recent conflict history shows that Iraq will disintegrate into Civil War again, once IS is driven out and US  troops are withdrawn. The religious divides plus outside involvement by bad actor sovereign states almost ensures localized tribe-dominated aims regardless of present alliances.
Because the trend is that the situation in Iraq is becoming less violent.
Daesh still a threat, little to lose. Iran has already won but may need some distractions from home front. Turkey always looking for distraction/lebensraum. Kurds unlikely to start anything IMO.

There are six big risks for Iraq:
1) The Kurds in the northern provinces who are requesting their autonomy,
2) the inner conflict between Shiites and Sunnis,
3) the iranian influence,
4) the saudi-arabian regional interests,
5) the aftermath of the war against ISIL and
6) the iraqi prime minister Nouri al-Maliqi.
1) and 2) are influencing one another - the Kurds mainly are Sunnites and will support the sunni side, but in exchange for concessions regarding their autonomy. 3) and 4) contradict each other - and influence 2), because the iranian population mostly consists of Shiites, whilst the saudi-arabian population mainly is sunni (simplified!). 5) depends strongly from 6) - al-Maliqi's decision for reconciliation or revenge will decide, if we will see the next outbreak of violence. Regarding his former decisions, al-Maliqi is not to be seen as a politician of reconciliation but as a some kind of seeder of contention. So there is a high risk for the outbreak of the next wave of violence.
Irak has known political and social unrest for long enough and is ready for more stability. I think they have learned from their mistakes.

While ISIS insurgency has been pinned down the variables have increased. The threat of other groups is still important to consider. Iraq suffers from a lack of infrastructure and is not a solidified nation.
There will be continued conflict in Iraq with civilian deaths
THE CURRENT POWER STRUCTURE IS LOOSING SUPPORT OF THE COMMON PEOPLE WHO ARE DESPERATE AND DEMAND CHANGE.
There will likely be more violence and conflict in Iraq in 2018 due to continued conflict with Islamic State.
That area will be unstable for at least the next generation.

The phony unity during ISIS campaign will bring a reaction.  Iraqis lost a million people for corrupt invasion.  U.S. wasnâ€™t greeted as liberator.  They will always hate us and will revolt against any hint of puppetry.
If anything happens with Iran it will happen.
Based upon history of the past

i firmly believe a major war will happen here.....there are to many sects of peoples fighting for this not to happen...and countries are involved in a major way..also very rich in oil and that always makes for disaster when fighting is involved.
